content: I'd like to thank @Recher and @Niako for their awesome feedback with this

One more remark : the context of the statement contains useless informations that looks like important one : the typing rate.

I would replace the first phrase by this one :
"In order to pass the United States Registered Professional Reporter test, you must be able to type a text with a very high (at least 90%) degree of accuracy. "

The statement is not clear enough concerning the calculation of accuracy.

The statement explains the characters should be compared case-insensitively. When reading this, we may believe that only the alphabetic characters should be considered. So it would be better to explicitly tell that even non-alphanumeric characters have to be considered, and that the comparison is case insensitive.

For example, with the test "Barely passed".

When considering all characters, the number of significant characters is 10. The scores are :

0.8
1.0
1.0
0.9
1.0
0.4
1.0
0.8
0.8

It is consistant with the expected answer.

If we believe only alphabetic characters should be considered, the number of significant ones is 9. The scores are :

0.7777777777777778
1.0
1.0
0.8888888888888888
1.0
0.3333333333333333
1.0
0.7777777777777778
0.7777777777777778

And it changes one of the pass/fail result.
Nice. Edited to replace "write true/false" by "write pass/fail" in the stub.

I see what you mean, that's why in the problem statement i described the method for calculating the accuracy using the length of the string instead of just the characters. The question could really be reformatted in for either case, however i think I'd like to leave it the way it is. I still greatly appreciate the feedback:

"The degree of accuracy can be calculated number of matching characters (case insensitive) divided by the length of the string."

Originally i was going to include a portion of needing to calculate the time as well as the accuracy, however i noticed it could be very complicated for a CoC problem to handle both of those issues within the narrow time frame. I left it in as a bit of neat trivia, since it doesn't seem to take up to much time/space on the screen. If I see similar comments suggesting its removal I'd be happy to do so. Thank you again for your comments
Right, however now that I think about it, it might be a good idea to emphasize the 90% (remove parenthesis, use bold font, etc) as it is crucial information here.

It makes sense to consider the space/punctuation chars as any other char in a typing test as they correspond to keys as well. However, as Recher suggests, it might be a good idea to mention it explicitly to avoid any ambiguity, e.g. "matching characters (spaces and punctuation included, case insensitive for alphabetic characters)".
